title-group.article-title: Statistical Methods for Analyzing Accident Riskâ€”A Prototype System

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1981 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: This paper discusses the problems and prospects for a system for statistically analyzing relationships between pre-crash factors and accidents using accident data from the National Accident Sampling System (NASS). The bulk of the paper presents a description and tentative results from a field trial of a prototype system in Monroe County, Indiana, using exposure data newly collected for the field trial and pre-existing accident data, The authors concluded that the development of such an analysis system, although difficult, was feasible if the objectives of such a system took into account the scarcity of accident data.

ref.mixed-citation: M.L. Squires, R.D. Hume, Y. Hochberg, H. Joksch, J. Reidy, D. Zaidel, D. Shinar, and J. Treat. "Accident Causation Methodology for the National Accident Sampling System." Pre- pared under contract to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Contract No. DOT-HS-7-01690. Mr. John R. Treat, now of the University of Michigan, was project director through most of the life of the contract.

J.R. Treat, et al. "Tri-Level Study of the Causes of Traffic Accidents: Final Report, Volumes I & II, March 31, 1977. Prepared under contract to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Contract No. DOT-HS- 034-3-535-77-TAC.
Raj, Wes (1976). Sampling Theory. McGraw Hill Book Company, New York, New York.
